paragraphs.text:
%md
### Note: This notebook will work properly only if you have configured your cluster for ML Manager. The Cloud Manager interface will allow you to enable ML Manager for your cluster.

msg.data: Note: This notebook will work properly only if you have configured your cluster for ML Manager. The Cloud Manager interface will allow you to enable ML Manager for your cluster.

Welcome to Splice Machine MLManager

The data platform for intelligent applications

Why use Splice Machine ML

Splice Machine ML isn't just a machine learning platform, it is a complete machine learning lifecycle management solution, giving you total control of your models, from retrieving data to scalable deployment.


  • Our platform runs directly on Apache Spark, allowing you to complete massive jobs in parallel
  • Our native PySpliceContext lets you directly access the data in your database and convert as a Spark DataFrame, no ETL.
  • MLFlow is integrated directly into all Splice Machine clusters, allowing you to keep track of your entire Data Science workflow
  • After you have found the best model for your task, you can easily deploy it live to AWS SageMaker or AzureML to make predictions in real time.
  • MLFlow does not force a standard workflow, instead it allows teams to develop their own methodology easily that fits their teams and problems

In this demo we will guide you through the entire MLManager life cycle.

Your friends at Splice Machine

How does this work?


Zeppelin

Zeppelin notebooks are a simple, easy and intuitive way to do data science, directly in your browser. Any Spark computations you run inside of the notebook are executed right on your cluster's Spark executors.

Zeppelin notebooks also make machine learning easier. By using Zeppelin intepreters, you can run different languages inside the same notebook. The language you want to run is signified by a % sign followed by an interpreter name at the top of a cell. For example, two of the interpreters you will become very familiar with while using our platform are the %spark.pyspark and %splicemachine interpreters. In the %splicemachine interpreter you can run standard SQL queries and visualize the results in Zeppelin's built in visulaization tools.

This entire demo was written inside a Zeppelin notebook

Splice Machine


MLFlow

As a data scientist constantly creating new models and testing new features, it is necessary to effectively track and manage those different ML runs. MLFlow allows you to track entire experiments and individual run parameters and metrics. The way you organize your flow is unique to you, and the intuitive Python API allows you to organize your delevopement process and run with it.

paragraphs.text:
%md

Ready? Let's get started.

## Problem statement: ### Can we predict the likelihood of fraudulent transactions after training on historical actuals? #### We're going to find out using Splice Machine's MLManager

msg.data:
Ready? Let's get started.

Problem statement:

Can we predict the likelihood of fraudulent transactions after training on historical actuals?

We’re going to find out using Splice Machine’s MLManager

paragraphs.text:
%angular

Connecting to your database



First, let's establish a connection to your database using Python via our Native Spark Datasource. We will use the SpliceMLContext to establish our direct connection-- it allows us to do inserts, selects, upserts, updates and many more functions without serialization

Splice Machine

msg.data:
Connecting to your database



First, let's establish a connection to your database using Python via our Native Spark Datasource. We will use the SpliceMLContext to establish our direct connection-- it allows us to do inserts, selects, upserts, updates and many more functions without serialization

Splice Machine

paragraphs.title: Create SpliceMLContext
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
from splicemachine.spark.context import SpliceMLContext
splice = SpliceMLContext(spark)

%splicemachine
create schema cc_fraud;
set schema cc_fraud;

drop table if exists cc_fraud_data;

create table cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data (
    time_offset integer,
    v1 double,
    v2 double,
    v3 double,
    v4 double,
    v5 double,
    v6 double,
    v7 double,
    v8 double,
    v9 double,
    v10 double,
    v11 double,
    v12 double,
    v13 double,
    v14 double,
    v15 double,
    v16 double,
    v17 double,
    v18 double,
    v19 double,
    v20 double,
    v21 double,
    v22 double,
    v23 double,
    v24 double,
    v25 double,
    v26 double,
    v27 double,
    v28 double,
    amount decimal(10,2),
    class_result int
);

call SYSCS_UTIL.IMPORT_DATA (
     'cc_fraud',
     'cc_fraud_data',
     null,
     's3a://splice-demo/kaggle-fraud-data/creditcard.csv',
     ',',
     null,
     null,
     null,
     null,
     100000,
     's3a://splice-demo/kaggle-fraud-data/bad',
     null, 
     null);

paragraphs.text:
%angular

Visualizing Your Data



Data Visualization

Visualizing your data is an extremely important part of machine learning. We can do this in the Splice Machine interpreter via a simple SQL SELECT query. Zeppelin has great built in visualization tools

Helpful Hint: the Splice Machine interpreter can be accessed with %splicemachine. Also ${a=default value} creates an input field in the Splice Machine interpreter. For this demo, we will use a fraudulent transaction dataset from Kaggle which has already been imported into this cluster's Splice Machine Database. The fields (features) have been anonymized to protect user identities. You can access the original data here.

Splice Machine

msg.data:
Visualizing Your Data



Data Visualization

Visualizing your data is an extremely important part of machine learning. We can do this in the Splice Machine interpreter via a simple SQL SELECT query. Zeppelin has great built in visualization tools

Helpful Hint: the Splice Machine interpreter can be accessed with %splicemachine. Also ${a=default value} creates an input field in the Splice Machine interpreter. For this demo, we will use a fraudulent transaction dataset from Kaggle which has already been imported into this cluster's Splice Machine Database. paragraphs.title: Huge data imbalance (very little fraud)
paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine
select class_result, count(*) from cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data group by class_result

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Fraud txns are on avg larger
paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine
select class_result, avg(amount) as average from cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data
group by class_result

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Bucketing txn amounts in fraud and non-fraud
paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine
drop table if exists cc_fraud.temp;

create table cc_fraud.temp as select
class_result,
case when(amount >= 0 and amount < 100) then 1 end as low,
case when(amount >= 100 and amount < 300) then 1 end as middle, 
case when (amount >= 300) then 1 end as high
from cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data;

select class_result,
(cast(count(low) as double))/count(*) as l, 
(cast(count(middle) as double))/count(*) as m, 
(cast(count(high) as double))/count(*) as h 
from cc_fraud.temp
group by class_result

%md
## We can also easily compare individual features to each other with Zeppelin and find possible correlations between them. More on this later.

paragraphs.title: There is a drastic change in feature values during certain times within fraud data
paragraphs.text:
%splicemachine
select v1, time_offset from cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data
where class_result = 1

paragraphs.text:
%angular

MLFlow Concepts



MLManager

  • Offers a way to interact with MLFlow directly from your Zeppelin Notebook
  • Allows you to use all basic operations to manipulate Experiments and Runs (create, update, delete etc.)
  • Accessible from splicemachine.ml.management.MLManager

Experiments
  • MLflow allows you to group runs under experiments, which can be useful for comparing runs intended to tackle a particular task.
  • You can use the MLManager class in the Splice Machine Python Package to manipulate experiments
  • They are visible in the left sidebar of the MLFlow Tracking UI (visible on port 5001)

Runs
  • MLflow Tracking is organized around the concept of runs, which are executions of some piece of data science code. Each run can record the following information
    • Metrics: model output metrics-- F1 score, AUC, Precision, Recall, R^2 etc. These map strings ("F1") to doubles (0.85)
    • Parameters: model parameters-- Num Trees, Preprocessing Steps, Regularization etc. These map strings ("classifier") to strings ("DecisionTree")
    • Models: fitted pipelines or models-- you can log models to deploy them to SageMaker later
    • Tags: pieces of information association of runs-- project, version, deployable. Maps strings ("deployable") to strings ("true")
Splice Machine

  • Allows you to use all basic operations to manipulate Experiments and Runs (create, update, delete etc.)

Experiments
  • MLflow allows you to group runs under experiments, which can be useful for comparing runs intended to tackle a particular task.
  • You can use the MLManager class in the Splice Machine Python Package to manipulate experiments
  • They are visible in the left sidebar of the MLFlow Tracking UI (visible on port 5001)

Runs
  • MLflow Tracking is organized around the concept of runs, which are executions of some piece of data science code. Each run can record the following information
    • Metrics: model output metrics-- F1 score, AUC, Precision, Recall, R^2 etc. These map strings ("F1") to doubles (0.85)
    • Parameters: model parameters-- Num Trees, Preprocessing Steps, Regularization etc. These map strings ("classifier") to strings ("DecisionTree")
    • Models: fitted pipelines or models-- you can log models to deploy them to SageMaker later
    • Tags: pieces of information association of runs-- project, version, deployable. Maps strings ("deployable") to strings ("true")
Splice Machine

paragraphs.text:
%md ### Let's create our MLManager


When you create an MLManager object, a tracking URL is returned to you. There is one tracking URL _per cluster_ so if you create another one in a new notebook, it will return the same tracking URL. This is useful because you can create multiple different experiments across all notebooks, and all will be tracked in the MLFlow UI.

Splice Machine

msg.data:
Let’s create our MLManager


When you create an MLManager object, a tracking URL is returned to you. There is one tracking URL per cluster so if you create another one in a new notebook, it will return the same tracking URL. This is useful because you can create multiple different experiments across all notebooks, and all will be tracked in the MLFlow UI.

Splice Machine

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
from splicemachine.ml.management import MLManager
manager = MLManager()

%angular

Loading The Data



Data Loading

Loading data into Splice Machine couldn't be easier, no matter the source. Because we connect directly to our database source, there is no ETL necessary.

Splice Machine

msg.data:
Loading The Data



Data Loading

Loading data into Splice Machine couldn't be easier, no matter the source. Because we connect directly to our database source, there is no ETL necessary.

Splice Machine

paragraphs.text: %md ### Let's import our data into a Spark DataFrame using our SpliceMLContext #### Now is also a good time to create our MLFlow Experiment which we will call fraud_demo

msg.data:
Let’s import our data into a Spark DataFrame using our SpliceMLContext

Now is also a good time to create our MLFlow Experiment which we will call fraud_demo

paragraphs.title: Import data and start experiment
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#create our MLFlow experiment
manager.create_experiment('fraud-demo')
manager.set_experiment('fraud-demo')
df = splice.df("SELECT * FROM cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data")
df = df.withColumnRenamed('CLASS_RESULT', 'label')
z.show(df)

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Data investigation
### Before going further, it's important to look at the correlations between all of your features and each other as well as the label
#### We can easily create a heatmap to compare all features against each other and the label

msg.data:
Data investigation

Before going further, it’s important to look at the correlations between all of your features and each other as well as the label

We can easily create a heatmap to compare all features against each other and the label

paragraphs.title: Compare Correlations of all columns
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

pdf = df.toPandas()
correlations = pdf.corr()
correlations.style.set_precision(2)

plt.rcParams["figure.figsize"] = (8,12)
plt.matshow(correlations, cmap='coolwarm')

ticks = [i for i in range(len(correlations.columns))]
plt.xticks(ticks, correlations.columns)
plt.yticks(ticks, correlations.columns)


plt.title('Fraud Data correlation heatmap')
plt.show()

%md # Ben's run ### Ben, our first Data Scientist, has an idea for the steps to build this model. He will create a run and log his name as to keep track of what he did #### manager.create_new_run(user_id='Ben') ##### Your user_id can be anything you want, and can be formatted to your team's liking, including names, dates or other identifiers, as long as it is in a string format.

msg.data:
Ben’s run

Ben, our first Data Scientist, has an idea for the steps to build this model. He will create a run and log his name as to keep track of what he did

manager.create_new_run(user_id=‘Ben’)

Your user_id can be anything you want, and can be formatted to your team’s liking, including names, dates or other identifiers, as long as it is in a string format.

paragraphs.text: %md ### If you navigate to port 5001 you will now see the fraud-demo experiment, but there is nothing in that experiment yet. Let's start our first run and track our progress

msg.data: If you navigate to port 5001 you will now see the fraud-demo experiment, but there is nothing in that experiment yet. Let’s start our first run and track our progress

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Because we have so few fraud examples, we need to oversample our fraudulent transactions and undersample the non-fraud transactions

msg.data: Because we have so few fraud examples, we need to oversample our fraudulent transactions and undersample the non-fraud transactions

paragraphs.title: First run (oversample data)
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#start our first MLFlow run
manager.create_new_run(user_id='Ben')
#oversample fraud data 2X
fraud_data = df.filter('label=1')
print('fraud data has {} rows'.format(fraud_data.count()))
fraud_data = fraud_data.unionAll(fraud_data)
print('fraud data has {} rows'.format(fraud_data.count()))
#log oversample rate
manager.log_param('oversample','2X')

#undersample non-fraud data 1:1
non_fraud_df = df.filter('label=0')

ratio = float(fraud_data.count())/float(df.count())
sampled_non_fraud = non_fraud_df.sample(withReplacement=False,fraction=ratio)

final_df = fraud_data.unionAll(sampled_non_fraud)
#log undersample ratio
manager.log_param('undersample', '1:1')
z.show(final_df)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text: %md ## Continuing through our feature engineering Pipeline: ### Now we create a Pipeline to normalize our continuous features using the StandardScaler and create our feature vector with the VectorAssembler #### We can be sure to log the steps we use in our preprocessing steps

msg.data:
Continuing through our feature engineering Pipeline:

Now we create a Pipeline to normalize our continuous features using the StandardScaler and create our feature vector with the VectorAssembler

We can be sure to log the steps we use in our preprocessing steps

paragraphs.title: Scale features and create feature-vector
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
from pyspark.ml.feature import StandardScaler, VectorAssembler
from pyspark.ml import Pipeline,PipelineModel
feature_cols = df.columns
feature_cols.remove("label")
print("Features: " + str(feature_cols))

assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=feature_cols, outputCol='features')
scaler = StandardScaler(inputCol="features", outputCol='scaledFeatures')
stages = [assembler, scaler]
#log preprocessing steps
manager.log_param('preprocessing','Pipeline[VectorAssembler, StandardScaler]')
#log features that we will use
for feature,i in zip(feature_cols,range(len(feature_cols))):
    manager.log_param('feature {}'.format(i),feature)
pipeline = Pipeline(stages=stages)
z.show(pipeline.fit(df).transform(df))

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text: %md ### Now Ben can train and run his model and view the results using our SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator and log the results to MLFlow #### The SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator is a library we created at Splice to make evaluating your models as simple as possible. For multiclass classification, we also have the SpliceMultiClassificationEvaluator and for regression, SpliceRegressionEvaluator

msg.data:
Now Ben can train and run his model and view the results using our SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator and log the results to MLFlow

The SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator is a library we created at Splice to make evaluating your models as simple as possible. For multiclass classification, we also have the SpliceMultiClassificationEvaluator and for regression, SpliceRegressionEvaluator

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
from pyspark.ml.classification import MultilayerPerceptronClassifier
from splicemachine.ml.utilities import SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator
import time

evaluator = SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator(spark)
first = len(feature_cols)
hidden = first/2
output = 2
layers = [first,hidden,output]
nn = MultilayerPerceptronClassifier(maxIter=100, layers=layers, blockSize=64, seed=5724, featuresCol='scaledFeatures')
manager.log_param('classifier', 'neural network')
manager.log_param('maxIter', '100')
manager.log_param('layers', '[{first}, {hidden}, 2]'.format(first=first,hidden=hidden))
manager.log_param('blockSize', '64')

df = df.repartition(50)
train, test = df.randomSplit([0.8,0.2])
t0 = time.time()
stages.append(nn)
full_pipeline = Pipeline(stages=stages)
model = full_pipeline.fit(train)
time_taken = time.time() - t0
print("Model took: " + str(time_taken) + " seconds to train")
#make predictions
predictions = model.transform(test)

evaluator.input(predictions)
z.show(evaluator.get_results())

#log how long the model took
manager.log_metric('time',time_taken)
# #log metrics for reference
vals = evaluator.get_results('dict')
for key in vals:
    manager.log_metric(key, vals[key])

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Run and evaluate model
View run and metrics in UI
paragraphs.text: %md

%md
### That model looks pretty accurate. Before moving forward, though, it's important to make sure that the model is generalizable to unbalanced data since it was trained on balanced data

msg.data: That model looks pretty accurate. Before moving forward, though, it’s important to make sure that the model is generalizable to unbalanced data since it was trained on balanced data

paragraphs.title: Test on unbalanced data
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#pull in full dataset
new_df = splice.df('select * from cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data')
new_df = new_df.withColumnRenamed('CLASS_RESULT', 'label')

#transform and run model on new dataframe
new_predictions = model.transform(new_df)

new_eval = SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator(spark)
new_eval.input(new_predictions)
z.show(new_eval.get_results())

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Great! Now we know that our model is not overfit and can be used in the future.
### Let's save the model to both s3 and as an MLFlow artifact, which we can later deploy to SageMaker for realtime use

msg.data:
Great! Now we know that our model is not overfit and can be used in the future.

Let’s save the model to both s3 and as an MLFlow artifact, which we can later deploy to SageMaker for realtime use

paragraphs.title: Save pipeline and model
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#save the pipeline and model to s3
model.write().overwrite().save('s3a://splice-demo/fraudDemoPipelineModel')
#save model to mlflow for deployment
manager.log_spark_model(model)

%md ## Amy's run ### Ben's run is saved in S3 and MLFlow and ready to be used, but Amy thinks she can build a stronger, quicker model. Amy will reimport the data and create a new Pipeline, by oversampling at a 1.5X rate and using a LogisticRegression model. #### She will start a new run with her name and keep track of her steps as well

msg.data:
Amy’s run

Ben’s run is saved in S3 and MLFlow and ready to be used, but Amy thinks she can build a stronger, quicker model. Amy will reimport the data and create a new Pipeline, by oversampling at a 1.5X rate and using a LogisticRegression model.

She will start a new run with her name and keep track of her steps as well

paragraphs.title: Import data and under/over sample
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
from pyspark.ml.classification import LogisticRegression
from pyspark.ml.feature import StandardScaler, VectorAssembler
from pyspark.ml import Pipeline,PipelineModel

#create new run
manager.create_new_run(user_id='Amy')
df = splice.df("SELECT * FROM cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data")
df = df.withColumnRenamed('CLASS_RESULT', 'label')


#oversample fraud data 1.5X
fraud_data = df.filter('label=1')
print('fraud data has {} rows'.format(fraud_data.count()))
#sample half the data
fraud_ratio = 0.5
half_fraud_data = fraud_data.sample(withReplacement=False,fraction=fraud_ratio)
#1.5X as many rows
fraud_data = fraud_data.unionAll(half_fraud_data)
print('fraud data has {} rows'.format(fraud_data.count()))
#log oversample rate
manager.log_param('oversample','1.5X')

#undersample non-fraud data 1:1
non_fraud_df = df.filter('label=0')

ratio = float(fraud_data.count())/float(df.count())
sampled_non_fraud = non_fraud_df.sample(withReplacement=False,fraction=ratio)

final_df = fraud_data.unionAll(sampled_non_fraud)
#log undersample ratio
manager.log_param('undersample', '1:1')

paragraphs.title: Scale and vectorize features
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#feature engineering
feature_cols = df.columns
feature_cols.remove("label")
print("Features: " + str(feature_cols))

#feature vector and scale features
assembler = VectorAssembler(inputCols=feature_cols, outputCol='features')
scaler = StandardScaler(inputCol="features", outputCol='scaledFeatures')
stages = [assembler, scaler]
#log preprocessing steps
manager.log_param('preprocessing','Pipeline[VectorAssembler, StandardScaler]')
#log features that we will use
for feature,i in zip(feature_cols,range(len(feature_cols))):
    manager.log_param('feature {}'.format(i),feature)

paragraphs.title: Model training and testing
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#build and evaluate model
evaluator = SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator(spark)
lr = LogisticRegression(featuresCol='scaledFeatures')
manager.log_param('classifier', 'logistic regression')
stages.append(lr)

df = df.repartition(50)
train, test = df.randomSplit([0.8,0.2])
t0 = time.time()
full_pipeline = Pipeline(stages=stages)
model = full_pipeline.fit(train)
time_taken = time.time() - t0
print("Model took: " + str(time_taken) + " seconds to train")
#make predictions
predictions = model.transform(test)

evaluator.input(predictions)
z.show(evaluator.get_results())

#log how long the model took
manager.log_metric('time',time_taken)
#log metrics for reference
vals = evaluator.get_results('dict')
for key in vals:
    manager.log_metric(key, vals[key])

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Test on unbalanced data
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#pull in full dataset
new_df = splice.df('select * from cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data')
new_df = new_df.withColumnRenamed('CLASS_RESULT', 'label')

#transform and run model on new dataframe
new_predictions = model.transform(new_df)

new_eval = SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator(spark)
new_eval.input(new_predictions)
z.show(new_eval.get_results())

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text: %md ## Amy can now go to the MLFlow UI and compare her results to Ben's ### Amy's run _was_ faster, but the accuracy didn't hold up and the False Positive Rate (FPR) was too high for fraud prediction #### Amy will save her run to S3 for future testing, but won't log it to MLFlow (yet)

msg.data:
Amy can now go to the MLFlow UI and compare her results to Ben’s

Amy’s run was faster, but the accuracy didn’t hold up and the False Positive Rate (FPR) was too high for fraud prediction

Amy will save her run to S3 for future testing, but won’t log it to MLFlow (yet)

paragraphs.text: %md ## You can also compare multiple runs side by side

msg.data: You can also compare multiple runs side by side

paragraphs.title: Save model to S3
paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
model.save('s3a://splice-demo/fraudDemoPipelineLogisticRegression')

%md
### A few days later, more labeled data comes in
#### Ben or Amy can easily pull the model in from S3 and run the new data through it to test for sustained accuracy

msg.data:
A few days later, more labeled data comes in

Ben or Amy can easily pull the model in from S3 and run the new data through it to test for sustained accuracy

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark
#load the fraud data from splicemachine
new_data = splice.df('select * from cc_fraud.cc_fraud_data')
#load NN model from s3
mod = PipelineModel.load('s3a://splice-demo/fraudDemoPipelineModel')
new_data = new_data.withColumnRenamed('CLASS_RESULT', 'label')

print('running model...')
preds = mod.transform(new_data)
eval = SpliceBinaryClassificationEvaluator(spark)
eval.input(preds)
z.show(eval.get_results())

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Model looks good! We can keep using it without fear of fraud

msg.data: Model looks good! We can keep using it without fear of fraud

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Just like that, multiple users can create runs, test their code, compare results, and log their models for easy deployment to Sagemaker.
#### For more information on Splice Machine and what we offer, feel free to read more [here](www.splicemachine.com)
